What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The class builds a strong basis in the biology of vertebrates and teaches good comparative and analytical skills.

This is a lecture course and provides a general survey of chordates (not technically just vertebrate) anatomy, with a focus on functional anatomy, evolutionary history, and comparisons between species. There is a bit of scientific writing in this class but since there isn't that much instruction on it and it's not terribly generalizable, the main skill you will be learning is just content knowledge and reasoning.

I learned a lot about the anatomy of vertebrates and what classifies and separates each clade, as well as the reasons for many of these adaptations and the logic of how some of their functional systems work. It got me thinking about why animals look and are built the way they are.
This course gave a good overview of the diversity of vertebrate anatomy and how new structures evolved through different species.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: lots of material taught in a fun and informative way with an engaging professor and very kind TAs. Weaknesses: very exam skewed grades and the in-class quizzes were very back loaded into the end of the semester.

The end portion of the course felt a bit like an afterthought, and just had some of the most difficult concepts of the semester all crammed into the last few classes of the semester. Additionally, exams consist of mostly memorization-based questions, and based on the sheer volume of content in the course (especially on the final) it felt like more emphasis should be put on reasoning-based questions, and/or the course should focus more on a smaller slice of content.
strengths: Dr. Moyer! He made lessons really engaging and entertaining!

Multiple-choice quizzes are just too difficult to have especially with the whole "select as many that apply", it just opens a bag of worms that leads to constantly second-guessing oneself. I would much rather prefer the whole exam to be open-answer questions, or diagram focused. I think it also tests our skills a lot more than multiple choice which is heavily dependent on one over the other

The course is very memorization heavy, although Prof. Moyer did make an effort to highlight the functional relationships between different concepts. I think that the way assessments are structured pushes students to study more through memorization rather than logical thinking, which could be improved.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: It's a really interesting course if you're interested in learning about every clade of vertebrates out there. There's a decent amount of memorization and some applied concepts.

If you need to take it, then it is certainly one where you will learn a lot of anatomy, but if you don't need to take it then I would recommend taking one of the E&EB electives (especially one of the ones for non-majors) instead, which tend to be less difficult and perhaps more interesting as well.
Yes, it isn't too hard at all and it is extremely interesting.
Yes! A chill course that's pretty interesting if you're into EEB, just make sure you actually spend time reviewing for exams because he writes them a bit tricky-- notihing unreasonable though!
Yes, but be prepared to study very hard before the tests. you literally never know what to expect.
Yes, if you are considering E&EB as a major or are considering pursuing a career in healthcare/biology, this course gives a good overview that can be applied to other courses/opportuntities.
Not unless it is required for their major
